utterances: Well, places where businesses are closed?
Right.
I went up to 116th Street on the east side.
That's an area known as Spanish Harlem.
The Spanish in New York are Puerto Ricans and Dominicans and Salvadorans, Guatemalans, and Mexicans.
Of course, the biggest group is Puerto Ricans.
That changes the dynamic because Puerto Ricans are, of course, U.S.
citizens.
So I've talked to Puerto Rican people and they talked about this day and they say, yes, some of my immigrant friends are not going to work.
Demographers say that actually Dominicans will soon become the largest Hispanic group in New York City.
What I did was I went to an area of Spanish Harlem, which was Second Avenue and 116th Street.
That's heavily Mexican.
There I met Gilbert Washington, who lives 100 blocks away.
He takes the subway up to Spanish Harlem to work maintenance.
He said the subway was empty.
There's a whole lot of difference.
There's hardly nobody out here.
Really.
Normally what would we be seeing?
Throngs of people coming in, to and fro, you know, getting in my way while I'm trying to sweep.
A few of the stores up there, I would say one out of every three or four, were closed.
But it was pretty random.
So the Mexico Lindo Grocery was closed.
But right next door, the Mexico Lindo Bakery was open and the workers in the bakery said the stores have two different owners, even though they're both called Mexico Lindo, which means pretty.
Oh, should I say it, Jay?
Yes, please.
Interestingly, after he lost Florida last week, he did not mount a huge national advertising buying in the days leading up to Super Tuesday.
He did advertise in California - he had an ad budget he said somewhere in the seven figure range.
But it was nothing like the kind of money, at least on a per capita basis that he had invested earlier in the race.
And that was taken by some as a sign that once he lost the Florida primary, even though he kept campaigning, Mitt Romney had rid the writing on the wall.
Mitt Romney as we heard earlier was very well regarded among very conservative Republicans.
He never quite stripped the criticism that he had reinvented himself for this race.
And whatever he did, in the way of changing positions, it didn't seem to work.
No, that's right.
As governor of Massachusetts, he had campaigned as a fiscal conservative but sort of a pragmatist and not someone overly concerned with social issues.
He reached out to social conservatist when he decided to run for president.
But he was out flagged on the right by Mike Huckabee.
He later retooled his message and stressed his economic credentials, his business background, but that didn't quite pull him out of the wind in Florida either.
Ultimately, Mitt Romney who is a very successful salesman was not able to close his biggest deal.
Okay.
Thanks, Scott.
My pleasure.
NPR's Scott Horsley who has been following the Romney campaign for months.
Let the buyer beware has long been a watchword and with good reason.
Well, you might say, order up some coffee beans and be alarmed to find when you got them home that a good two thirds of it might consist of dried peas instead of coffee beans.
You might get milk.
It would contain water, be it watered down.
But it would be bulked up again with things like plaster of Paris or flower or sheep's brains, most infamously.
Don't worry, this is not a new round of tainted products from China.
It's a list of domestic goods.
Americans might have bought a century and a half ago.
Back then, out country was notorious for tainted food, shoddy merchandise, and intellectual piracy.
The voice you heard listing those grocery store horrors is Stephen Mihm, a professor of American history at the University of Georgia.
You'd find these things right here in the United States.
Any store might had contained things that were really kind of low quality - that have been adulterated, that had been counterfeited.
It was a time when as capitalism really kind of took off in this country, this sort of existing means regulating it was often that was not up to the task.

And so people didn't necessarily have something like the FDA they could go to or to any of the other federal agencies that now today ensure, or at least we hope ensure, a certain degree of quality of our goods.
What other kinds of unscrupulous business practices were going on in the 19th century?
It's interesting.
This is a time when, you know, when we say making money had a very literal as well as a figurative meaning.
And that the money supply originated not with the federal government, but with private banks that printed their own money.
And counterfeiters at this time had a field day counterfeiting this money and adding, you know, spurious currency into the monetary system.
It was a time when there was a tremendous amount of commercial fraud whether that was in stocks, land speculation.
What about intellectual piracy back then?
Were they selling black market copies of ""Little Women"" on street corners?
Well, not so much American authors - they were protected.
It was the foreign authors who were really taking it on the chin.
Charles Dickens, when he showed up to visit the United States in 1842 was shocked to find that essentially American publishers were freely pirating his books, and he was outraged about this.
When he raised this issue with his American hosts, they just shrug their shoulders and sort of look at him like, what was wrong with this?
You know, this is what we do here.
We pirate things and we don't necessarily compensate you for it.
It was really an era that is very much analogous, obviously, to China today.
It was an era that seems really foreign to us.
But in many respects lies at the foundation of our own country's economic development.
What was going on?
Why was counterfeiting so rampant during that time in America?
Counterfeiting seems to flourish and fraud seems to flourish at times when capitalism and economic growth is outpacing the ability of a society to control it.
What's interesting though, in some respects, is all this counterfeiting is helping to propel the economic growth as well.
Counterfeiting money can do the job, this is as well as genuine money and underwriting economic growth under the right circumstances.
And see, you can even argue that America's economic growth at certain points in the 19th century was fueled in those small part by a lot of fraud and a lot of counterfeiting.
How did America's trade partners react?
They were increasingly angry, especially as they began to suffer from bad American products.
It was one thing for Americans to poison themselves.
It was all together another thing for American pork to show up in, say, German in the 1870s carrying trichinosis.
And many European countries would slap embargos or essentially slap boycotts on American products.
They also were very found of lecturing the United States.

And Charles Dickens was only one of many European authors who do this, who was trying to get the Americans to adapt an international copyright law which they finally did in 1891 - a little too late to help Charles Dickens - but a lot of lecturing, some boycotts, trade threats, retaliation.
That helped but it took a long time for America to work out its kinks in its system.
Stephen Mihm is an assistant professor of American history at the University of Georgia.
His new book is ""A Nation of Counterfeiters.
Thank you for talking with us.
Thank you.
And now, back to Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice's mission to the Middle East and the renewed talk about the Israeli-Palestinian peace plan that Saudi Arabia proposed in 2002.
(As Max) Buck, nice.
Hey, don't smoke in here, OK, man?
I'm trying to see smaller communities far away from the glitter of Vegas.
I've been driving down Highway 50 all across the state, from California to Utah.
It's called the loneliest road in America.
But maybe it's not going to be so lonely in the next couple of days and months.
The political campaigns are coming here because Nevada is growing more important.
You'll hear more voices from here tomorrow.
But I want to begin today with an interview from Reno.
To explain what's happening here, we went to the head of the political science department at the University of Nevada at Reno.
He's Erik Herzik.
And he told us that the political significance of Nevada and its caucuses, it sort of ebbs and flaws.
Before other states started moving into the cue, we were very important, then it kind of went away as states started to move up.
It's come back to be very important, particularly for, say, Hillary Clinton, who seemed to be running away with everything, has now stubbed her toe, and Nevada could be a firewall for her.
Let's go past the caucuses now to the general election next fall.
I have heard - there are ideas, actually - that Nevada could be a swing state, like Illinois and Florida in the last two elections.
The whole election could turn on Nevada.
Sketch out a scenario for me in which that would be the case.
Well, I think it's easy because Nevada has been a swing state.
Most people don't know this, but since 1912 Nevada has voted for the winner in every presidential election except 1976.
We're not a state with strong partisan leanings.
We're not a state with strong partisan organization.
So we're not in anybody's column.
We voted for Bill Clinton twice, George Bush twice.
And I don't know that Nevadans liked either one of them.
Because we're not in any particular column, Nevada, we're up for grabs.
Had Al Gore done two percentage points better in Nevada, Florida would have been irrelevant that night.
If Nevada turned out to be a place where the national election was decided, how would it have been decided?
And what I mean by that is, what are candidates going to have to say to win Nevada, a Republican or a Democrat?
There's not a pat answer to this.
Nevada is not a particularly partisan state.

If you're a Republican and you start talking about, say, the Christian right or the social agenda, that's not going to work too well in a state that's built on legalized gambling, has legalized prostitution, and the bars never close.

On the flipside, if you're a Democrat, Northeastern Democrat, and you start coming out here and talking about the industrial job loss, people are just going to roll their eyes and say, wait a minute, we're a service economy.
So the candidates have to at least tailor their messages away from the core message of their party that you may find in other regions.
Then it also just gets down to which candidate, in a sense, people trust or like the best.
I think this is what hurt John Kerry.

John Kerry came out and was seen as an aloof Easterner and, you know, while Nevada can somewhat be looked down upon by the rest of the nation, we will return the favor if when a lead Easterner comes out and starts talking down to us.
And I think that happened to John Kerry.
Which Republican candidates do you think are doing well in Nevada?
Well, very few of them have really made much of an effort.
Mitt Romney is the only one with a semblance of an organization.
Being a Mormon does not hurt him in Nevada.
Ron Paul has a presence here, a lot of independent expenditures.
You see more, say, signage and ads for him on the Republican side.
After that, it drops off dramatically.
John McCain will say, look, I'm a fellow Westerner.
I talk straight.
Kind of pull out all the western cliches and I'm from the neighboring state and hope that's enough.
After that, you know, Giuliani has come here and raised a lot of money, but really hasn't campaigned in this state.
Huckabee has no natural draw here.
Fred Thompson, you know, that just doesn't work, their styles in Nevada.
Professor Herzik, as we head out down Route 50, the loneliest highway in America, is there one political voice out there we should look for, one person we should stop and get off the road and go see?
I don't know if there's one person to listen to, but - and this maybe reflects the dynamics of the rural vote, A.M. radio is important in rural - rural Nevada.
There are long distances to drive and that might be the only kind of frequency that comes in.
And so the voices you hear on A.M. radio often time are the voices that are being heard in rural Nevada.
Eric Herzik, professor at the University of Nevada, Reno, where he's chair of the political science department.
Professor, thank you.
It was my pleasure.

Okay, and I'll just to tell you, I have been listening to the radio, and tomorrow I am going to play you one of the greatest station IDs in American broadcasting - when we are coming to you tomorrow from Eureka, Nevada on the loneliest road in America.
